Award.AbstractNarration:
This is funding to support a doctoral research symposium (workshop) of approximately 8 promising doctoral students along with 4 distinguished research faculty. The event will take place in conjunction with and immediately preceding the 24th ACM Symposium on User Interface Software and Technology (UIST 2011), to be held October 16-19, in Santa Barbara, California, and sponsored by the Association for Computing Machinery's Special Interest Group on Human Computer Interaction (SIGCHI). The annual UIST conference is the premier international forum for presenting innovative research results as well as implementation experiences in the software and technology of human computer interaction. It brings together researchers and practitioners from diverse areas that include traditional graphical and web user interfaces, tangible and ubiquitous computing, virtual and augmented reality, multimedia, new input and output devices, and computer-supported cooperative work. More information about the conference may be found at http://www.acm.org/uist.

This year's doctoral research symposium will be just the 9th such workshop associated with the UIST conferences (NSF has offered support for these events from their inception). The three goals of this full-day event are to increase the exposure and visibility of the participants' work within the community, to help establish a sense of community among this next generation of researchers, and to help foster their research efforts by providing substantive feedback and guidance from a group of senior researchers in a supportive and interactive environment. To these ends, student participants will each make formal 20-minute presentations of their work to the group, to be followed by an extensive discussion lasting approximately 30 minutes during which they will receive feedback from a faculty panel; the feedback is geared to helping students understand and articulate how their work is positioned relative to other research, whether their topics are adequately focused for thesis research projects, whether their methods are correctly chosen and applied, and whether their results are appropriately analyzed and presented. The students will also present their research to a wider audience through posters at the conference poster reception, brief overviews during the conference overview session, and short papers in the Conference Companion and DVD.

Broader Impacts: The doctoral symposium will help expand the participation of young researchers pursuing graduate studies in the field of user interface software and technology, by providing them an opportunity to gain wider exposure in the community for their innovative work and to obtain feedback and guidance from senior members of the research community. It will further help foster a sense of community among these young researchers, by allowing them to create a social network both among themselves and with senior researchers at a critical stage in their professional development. Because the students and faculty constitute a diverse group across a variety of dimensions, the students' horizons are broadened to the future benefit of the field. The organizers of the event will make special efforts to attract students from institutions not historically heavily represented at UIST and to foster diversity across under-represented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported the Doctoral Symposium at the 2011 ACM Symposium
on User Interface Software and Technology (UIST), which was held in
Santa Barbara, CA, starting the Saturday before UIST itself (October
15, 2011).  The Doctoral Symposium was intended to help expand the
participation of young researchers currently pursuing Ph.D. studies in
this vital research area, giving their innovative work wider exposure
in the community, helping to foster a sense of community among these
young researchers, and providing an opportunity for them to obtain
feedback and guidance from senior members of the research community in
an interactive and supportive environment.

The Doctoral Symposium was chaired by Prof. Steven Feiner (Columbia
University), and attended by three additional faculty members and
seven selected Ph.D. students.

Increased visibility was accomplished through publication in the UIST
Conference Adjunct Proceedings of four-page position papers written by
the students.  Students also presented posters at an event attended by
conference participants.

The primary activity of the symposium was a day-long series of
presentations by the student participants.  Each student presented
their work to the group for 20 minutes, followed by a 25 minute
discussion amongst group members. Discussions were guided by the
committee members mentoring the symposium to highlight the strengths
of the work, challenges and issues, implications of the results, and
potential suggestions for additional approaches or follow-on work.

To summarize the intellectual merit of the UIST Doctoral Symposium, it
provided valuable feedback to young researchers on the research they
are performing for their doctoral studies. It assisted them in
analyzing and presenting their current research and in planning the
remaining research needed to complete their dissertation requirements.

To summarize the broader impacts of the UIST Doctoral Symposium, it
served an education and career development role for young researchers
who are advancing a field that emphasizes the design of user
interfaces to make computers easier to use effectively by members of
the public at large.
